questions.text: Which census method is used in India?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The census method used in India is primarily based on the De Jure system.

De Jure System:

  • In the De Jure system, individuals are counted based on their legal status or residency at a particular location, irrespective of whether they are physically present there during the census period.
  • This method is suitable for countries like India, where large populations are mobile, and people might be absent from their usual place of residence during the census period due to various reasons such as work, travel, or temporary relocation.
  • India's census enumerators visit households and record information about individuals based on their legal residence, including those who may be away at the time of the census.
  • The De Jure system ensures a comprehensive count of the population, including individuals who are temporarily absent but are legally residents of a particular area.

Explanation of Other Options:

De Facto system (Option A): Individuals are counted based on their physical presence at the time of census, which may undercount mobile populations.

Both (Option C): Some countries may use a mix, but India predominantly follows only the De Jure method for uniformity.

None (Option D): India conducts a census using an established De Jure method; not conducting a census would hinder demographic planning.

questions.text:
True regarding the census of India:

A. Done by the Ministry of Home Affairs
B. Done every 5 yrs.
C. Census Commissioner is the supreme head
D. First started in 1851
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The true statements regarding the Indian census are A and C.

  • Done by the Ministry of Home Affairs (Option A):
    • The census is conducted by the Office of the Registrar General and Census Commissioner, which operates under the Ministry of Home Affairs, Government of India.
    • This ensures centralized control and coordination of nationwide data collection and processing.
  • Census Commissioner is the Supreme Head (Option C):
    • The Census Commissioner is the top authority for planning, conducting, and managing the census operation in India.
    • They hold responsibility for ensuring the accuracy, completeness, and integrity of census data.
  • Incorrect Statements:
    • Done every 5 years (Option B): The census in India is carried out every 10 years, not every 5.
    • First started in 1851 (Option D): While some population counts were done earlier, the first synchronous and complete Indian census was in 1881, not 1851.

(Other options ruled out)

questions.text: The census population count is in reference to:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The population is counted as per the reference date and time known as the Census moment, which is 00:00 hrs of 1st March.

  • Census enumeration is carried out in the last week of February and ends on 28th/29th February.
  • The reference time for all population data collected is taken as midnight of 1st March.
  • This ensures a fixed point in time to avoid duplication or omission in the count.

Explanation of Other Options:

1st July (Option B): Used to estimate mid-year population, not census count.

30th June (Option C): Not used in census enumeration; irrelevant date.

1st January (Option D): Too early in the year and not aligned with the enumeration schedule.

questions.text: According to 2011 census, life expectancy at birth in India is:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The correct answer is option C: 66.6 years. This figure corresponds to the life expectancy at birth as per the 2011 census.

  • Life expectancy at birth is a statistical measure indicating the average number of years a newborn is expected to live if current mortality rates remain constant.
  • According to the 2011 census data, life expectancy at birth in India was reported to be approximately 66.6 years.
  • This figure is derived from comprehensive demographic data collected during the census, including mortality rates and population estimates.
  • It reflects improvements in healthcare, sanitation, and overall living conditions in the country.

Explanation of Other Options:

63 years (Option A): Does not correspond to the life expectancy reported in the 2011 census; lower than the national average.

64.6 years (Option B): This figure does not align with the national average from 2011; although life expectancy may vary slightly by region, this value is not correct.

74 years (Option D): This figure is closer to life expectancy in developed nations and is not reflective of India's data from the 2011 census.

questions.text: According to 2020, life expectancy at birth in females is:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The correct answer is option D: 74 years. This figure corresponds to the life expectancy at birth for females in the year 2020.

  • Life expectancy at birth is the average number of years a newborn is expected to live, assuming current mortality rates remain constant.
  • As per demographic data for 2020, the life expectancy at birth for females in India was reported to be approximately 74 years.
  • This reflects significant improvements in healthcare access, medical advancements, and socioeconomic conditions, contributing to increased longevity among females.

Explanation of Other Options:

36.7 years (Option A): This figure is unrealistically low and not representative of any modern population, especially not for the year 2020.

63 years (Option B): This is lower than the actual life expectancy for females in 2020 and is inconsistent with national data.

70 years (Option C): While plausible, this underestimates the life expectancy figure reported specifically for females in 2020.

questions.text: Births in India must be registered within:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The correct answer is option C: 21 days. In India, births must be registered within 21 days of their occurrence, as mandated by the Registration of Births and Deaths Act, 1969.

  • This legally prescribed timeframe ensures that the birth of a child is officially recorded and the child receives legal recognition from the state.
  • The 21-day window provides adequate time for parents or guardians to gather required documents and approach local authorities for birth registration.
  • Timely registration facilitates access to essential services, legal rights, and benefits such as issuance of birth certificates, school admissions, and identity documents.

Explanation of Other Options:

7 days (Option A): Although early registration is encouraged, Indian law allows up to 21 days for official birth registration, making this timeframe incorrect.

14 days (Option B): While this period falls within the permitted range, it does not reflect the actual mandated duration of 21 days.

1 month (Option D): Although some delays may be condoned with a late fee or permission, the legal requirement under Indian law is to register within 21 days.

choices.text: 21 days of arrival to India
60 days of arrival to India

questions.text: A child born to Indian couples outside India, birth must be registered within:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The correct answer is option D: 60 days of arrival to India. This is the legal timeframe within which the birth of a child born abroad to Indian parents must be registered after their return to India.

  • The registration of such births is governed by the Registration of Births and Deaths Act, 1969.
  • When an Indian couple gives birth to a child outside India, the birth is required to be registered with the Indian authorities within 60 days of their arrival back in India.
  • This duration allows sufficient time for the parents to compile and submit the necessary documentation for official registration.
  • Registration ensures the child is legally recognised in India and eligible for official identity documents and entitlements.

Explanation of Other Options:

21 days (Option A): This applies only to births occurring within India and is not relevant for children born abroad.

21 days of arrival to India (Option B): While this refers to the return of parents to India, the permitted registration window is longer - 60 days, not 21.

60 days (Option C): This suggests registration from the date of birth, regardless of the parent's location, which is inaccurate in the context of overseas births.

questions.text: Which of the following is the national-level system that provides annual national as well as state-level reliable estimates of fertility and mortality?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The Sample Registration System (SRS) is a national-level mechanism that generates annual, reliable estimates of fertility and mortality rates at both the national and state levels.

  • Operates under the Office of the Registrar General & Census Commissioner, India.
  • Provides continuous demographic data through dual record systems (continuous enumeration and half-yearly survey).
  • Uses a scientific sample design to ensure national and state-level representation.
  • Collects data on births, deaths, and other vital events.
  • Serves as the most reliable source for fertility and mortality statistics in India between decennial censuses.

Explanation of Other Options:

Civil Registration System (Option A): Records vital events like births and deaths legally, but suffers from under-registration and does not consistently provide reliable annual estimates for all states.

Census (Option B): Conducted once every 10 years; provides detailed demographic data, but is not designed to deliver annual fertility and mortality rates.

Ad-hoc Survey (Option C): Refers to non-regular, purpose-specific surveys; lacks the continuity and representativeness needed for reliable national-level fertility and mortality estimates.

Key Takeaways:

The Sample Registration System (SRS) is specifically designed to provide annual, reliable estimates of fertility and mortality at both national and state levels, making it the most appropriate choice.

questions.text: NFHS has successfully completed how many rounds?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The National Family Health Survey (NFHS) is a large-scale, nationwide demographic and health survey conducted in India by the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare, with technical support from IIPS and other partners.

  • NFHS gathers extensive information on population, health, family welfare, and nutrition.
  • It plays a key role in monitoring and evaluating health and population programs.
  • As of the latest data, five rounds of NFHS have been successfully completed.
  • These rounds have helped track trends in fertility, mortality, maternal and child health, contraceptive use, and other health indicators over time.
  • NFHS-5 is the most recent completed round, enabling comparison and analysis of changes over previous rounds.

Explanation of Other Options:

One (Option A): Incorrect, as the NFHS has completed more than one round. Limiting to one round would not provide sufficient longitudinal data for health policy formulation.

Two (Option B): Also incorrect, since multiple rounds beyond two have been conducted. Two rounds alone cannot reflect long-term demographic transitions.

Three (Option C): Inadequate, because although three rounds would provide some time-trend data, the NFHS has progressed further and completed five rounds.

Key Takeaways:

Option D is correct as the NFHS has successfully completed five rounds, each providing critical data for health and population policymaking in India.

Explanation:

The correct answer is option B: Morbidity. Demographic processes primarily refer to population dynamics, specifically fertility, mortality, and migration (or social mobility), which influence the size, composition, and distribution of a population.

  • Morbidity refers to the prevalence or incidence of disease within a population.
  • It is a health indicator, not a demographic parameter.
  • Although morbidity affects public health planning, it is not used to measure population dynamics like birth and death statistics are.
  • Thus, morbidity is not classified as a demographic process.

Explanation of Other Options:

Fertility (Option A): A core demographic process that involves the measurement of birth rates and reproductive behaviour. It directly influences population growth and structure.

Mortality (Option C): A key demographic process that includes the study of death rates and life expectancy. It plays a vital role in demographic transition models.

Social Mobility (Option D): While traditionally a sociological concept referring to movement within social hierarchies, it is included in broader discussions of demographic change due to its link to migration and socioeconomic dynamics.

questions.text: Which of the following involves reproductive women?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The correct answer is option B: GFR (General Fertility Rate). It is the most specific measure among the options that directly involves reproductive-age women, usually defined as those aged 15-49 years.

  • GFR quantifies the number of live births per 1,000 women of reproductive age in a given year.
  • It is a focused fertility indicator used to assess fertility behaviour in this specific population group.
  • By limiting the denominator to women aged 15-49, it offers a more accurate estimate of fertility activity compared to broader measures like the birth rate.

Explanation of Other Options:

BR (Birth Rate) (Option A): Birth rate is calculated as the number of live births per 1,000 individuals in the total population. It does not isolate reproductive-age women, and thus is less specific than GFR for fertility analysis.

TFR (Total Fertility Rate) (Option C): TFR estimates the average number of children a woman would bear during her reproductive years based on current age-specific fertility rates. Although it pertains to reproductive women, it is a projected/aggregate estimate, not a direct measure of current reproductive activity.

MMR (Maternal Mortality Ratio) (Option D): MMR is a mortality indicator, measuring maternal deaths per 100,000 live births. It reflects health risk during pregnancy, but does not measure fertility and does not directly represent the fertility behaviour of reproductive women.

Key Takeaways:

Among the given choices, GFR is the only demographic measure that directly involves reproductive-age women in its calculation, making it the most specific fertility indicator in this context.

questions.text: The system of collection of data to give national and subnational estimates of vital indicators, consisting of continuous enumeration backed by a 6-month survey, is:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The correct answer is option C: Sample Registration Survey (SRS). It is a unique system designed to provide continuous and reliable demographic data at national and subnational levels.

  • SRS involves a dual record system that combines continuous enumeration by local part-time enumerators and an independent six-month retrospective survey by supervisors.
  • It is conducted by the Office of the Registrar General of India (ORGI).
  • The system is used to estimate key vital indicators such as birth rate, death rate, infant mortality rate (IMR), and more.
  • SRS is the only system in India providing annual national and sub-national estimates through such a continuous and sample-based method, making it crucial for demographic planning and health policy formulation.

Explanation of Other Options:

Model Registration Survey (Option A): There is no recognised national-level data collection mechanism by this name for continuous enumeration and 6-month survey-based vital statistics. Hence, this option is incorrect.

National Sample Survey (Option B): The National Sample Survey (NSS) collects large-scale socio-economic data such as employment, consumption, and education. It does not focus on vital events like births or deaths, and it does not use a 6-month survey-backup method.

National Family Health Survey (Option D): The NFHS is a periodic survey focused on health and family welfare indicators, such as maternal and child health, fertility, and contraception. It does not involve continuous enumeration or biannual surveys, making it unsuitable for the function described in the question.

Key Takeaways:

The Sample Registration Survey (SRS) is the only national-level system that provides annual, reliable, and representative estimates of fertility and mortality using continuous enumeration backed by a 6-month retrospective survey.

questions.text: The National Population Stabilisation Fund is aimed at achieving population stabilisation at a level consistent with the needs of sustainable economic growth, social development, and environmental protection by:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The correct answer is option D: 2045. The National Population Stabilisation Fund (NPSF) is a governmental initiative aimed at stabilising India's population in alignment with the country's sustainable economic growth, social development, and environmental protection goals. The target year set for this achievement is 2045.

  • The NPSF aims to promote voluntary and informed choices for family planning.
  • The 2045 target reflects the long-term demographic challenges India faces and underscores the need for sustained efforts.
  • Population stabilisation at this level will aid in balancing resource availability with population needs, improving the quality of life.

Explanation of Other Options:

2015 (Option A): This year has already passed and was not a realistic timeline given India's demographic trajectory. It is not associated with the NPSF goals.

2030 (Option B): Although 2030 is a major benchmark year for Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs), it is not the specific target year for population stabilisation under the NPSF.

2040 (Option C): While closer to the correct answer, 2040 is still not the official year cited by the government. The officially stated target is 2045, to allow for gradual and sustainable progress.

Key Takeaways:

The National Population Stabilisation Fund targets the year 2045 for achieving population stabilisation consistent with India's economic, social, and environmental needs. This long-term goal reflects the complexity and gradual nature of population-related policy implementation.

questions.text: State used as a yardstick of health in India:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The correct answer is option B: Kerala, as it is widely regarded as the benchmark for health indicators in India due to its outstanding health outcomes and public health infrastructure.

Why Kerala is considered the yardstick of health in India:

  • High Life Expectancy: Kerala consistently records one of the highest life expectancies in the country, significantly above the national average, reflecting better healthcare access and quality of life.
  • Low Infant Mortality Rate (IMR): Kerala's IMR is among the lowest in India, demonstrating strong maternal and child health services, effective immunisation, and antenatal care.
  • High Literacy Rate: Kerala has the highest literacy rate in India, which directly correlates with better health awareness, preventive care utilisation, and healthier lifestyle choices.
  • Robust Public Healthcare System: The state has a widespread and efficient public healthcare network, including well-functioning primary health centres and hospitals that ensure universal health coverage.
  • Focus on Social Development: Kerala's model of development emphasises healthcare, education, and welfare. This integrated approach has led to overall better health outcomes across its population.

Explanation of Other Options:

Tamil Nadu (Option A): Though Tamil Nadu has shown impressive progress in healthcare delivery and maternal services, it is not as consistently used as a benchmark as Kerala.

Andhra Pradesh (Option C): Andhra Pradesh has made health improvements, but it doesn't achieve the same level of comprehensive outcomes as Kerala.

Gujarat (Option D): Gujarat has implemented several public health initiatives, but it is not considered the standard for health metrics in India.

questions.text: Vital statistics in a population include:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The correct answer is option C: Birth rate.

  • Vital statistics refer to quantitative data related to vital events in a population, such as births, deaths, marriages, and divorces. These statistics are essential for understanding population dynamics and for effective public health and policy planning.
  • From the standard reference image, birth rate is shown as one of the primary indicators used in demographic tables to monitor fertility trends, making it a key component of vital statistics.

Examples of Vital Statistics (as per standard sources):

  • Birth rate (e.g., 18.7 in India, 12.4 in the USA)
  • Death rate (e.g., 7.2 in India, 8.7 in the USA)
  • Infant mortality rate
  • Maternal mortality rate
  • Marriage and divorce rates (not shown in this image but classified under vital statistics in Park)

Explanation of Other Options:

Age composition (Option A): Refers to the distribution of the population by age group. While useful in demographic studies, it is not classified under vital statistics.

Sex ratio (Option B): Indicates the number of males per 100 females in a population. It is a demographic indicator, but not a vital statistic.

Dependency ratio (Option D): Refers to the ratio of dependent age groups (0-14 and 65+) to the working-age population (15-64). It is an economic-demographic indicator, not a vital statistic.

questions.text: Movement at the socio-economic level is:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The correct answer is Social mobility, which refers to the movement of individuals or groups within a social hierarchy, typically marked by changes in socio-economic indicators like income, occupation, education, and social status.

Key features of Social Mobility:

  • Involves upward, downward, or horizontal movement in social hierarchy.
  • It can occur across generations (intergenerational) or within a person's lifetime (intragenerational).
  • Indicates dynamic changes in the socio-economic landscape of a society.

Explanation of Other Options:

Social equality (Option A): Refers to equal rights and opportunities for all individuals, regardless of their social or economic background. It is an ideal state, whereas social mobility is a measurable process of movement.

Socio-economic upliftment (Option C): Describes broad interventions to improve economic and social conditions (e.g., poverty reduction programs). It is an outcome, not the process of movement.

Social mobilisation (Option D): Involves collective action and engagement of communities for social or political causes. It may support policies enabling mobility, but it is conceptually distinct.

Key Takeaways:

Social mobility specifically denotes the movement across different socio-economic levels, making it the most appropriate answer among the given choices.

questions.text: Birth rate and death rate are measured at the state and national levels by:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The Civil Registration System (CRS) is the primary and permanent system used for the legal recording of vital events, including births and deaths, as per national laws. It is implemented uniformly across the country and provides continuous and complete data, enabling the direct computation of birth and death rates at both the national and subnational levels.

  • Legally mandated and continuous process.
  • Records individual events in real-time.
  • Enables the generation of vital statistics such as birth rate and death rate with high accuracy.
  • Essential for public health planning and demographic analysis.

Comparison Table: Civil Registration System (CRS) vs. Sample Registration System (SRS)

Explanation of Other Options:

Census (Option A): Though it provides detailed demographic profiles every 10 years, it does not directly measure birth or death rates; rather, it provides estimates based on population size and structure.

Sample Registration System (SRS) (Option C): A sample-based system introduced to supplement the civil registration system, providing reliable estimates of fertility and mortality indicators through dual record mechanism. However, it is not the primary or legal source for recording individual births and deaths.

National Family Health Survey (NFHS) (Option D): A large-scale periodic survey that gathers information on reproductive health, family planning, nutrition, and mortality through household interviews. It is useful for program evaluation, but not a primary system for direct measurement of birth and death rates.
